The problem is, at 35,000 feet the partial pressure of oxygen is too low to allow for adequate absorption of oxygen which will lead to hypoxia; unconsciousness; and eventually death. The masks are desgined to increase the oxygen available to the passengers and crew until the aircraft can be brought down to safe altitude where the partial pressure of oxygen is sufficient to allow people to breathe without the mask. 
 
 
You won't be sucked out of a little hole, or even a broken window. But if the structural integrity of a plain fails at high altitude and high speeds the hole can get a lot bigger fast. 

 Structural deformation of the aircraft due to loss of pressurization is an extremely rare occurance. Loss of pressurization due to structural failure is much more common. Meaning, a bullet hole will not typically cause an airplane to come apart in flight. 
 
 
But even if what you say is true, and the bullets won't harm the plain, then I still think it's a bad idea to have a shoot-out in a highly cramped space, at 8km.

 Certain rights are universal, in that unless those who enjoy their protection grant that same protection to everyone else, they are not rights at all, but only privileges. Thus, wherever human execution is legal, the 'right' to life is demoted to a privilege, an arbitrary local custom.
 
 WRT to the "right" to bear arms, unless every individual can and does bear arms, it, too, is nothing but a privileged status arbitrarily awarded to some, but not others.
 
 Since the notion of a modern society in which all members, at all times, can and do carry the most fearsome weapons they are able to, according to their physical abilities, is simply insane, can we not let the notion of universal right to 'bear-arms' drop with a well-deserved thud?
 
 When it comes to arbitrarily granted privileges, such as driver's permits, hunting permits, and gun permits, there should be an assumption that any applicant must first prove themselves as meeting certain specified basic requirements before being granted that privilege. This is true everywhere wrt motor vehicle and driver's permits, and pretty much universal with regard to hunting permits, or any other activity which could potentially put other people, privileged or or not, at risk of their health or property or liberty.
 
 You do not get to be a cop or a soldier in most modern countries simply by walking up and offering to pay cash for a gun, a tank, or a rocket launcher. You have to go through a series of mental, physical, and emotional tests before you are accepted. If that is good enough for the police and the military, why is it not good enough for everybody? Without a full bank of physical, mental, and emotional tests and background checks with positive results, a person should have no privileged gun-toting status. And no-one should be able to sell or trade such arms without an equally rigourous licensing procedure.
 
 Since, after such requirements, those granted the privilege will walk about with much greater maim and kill capacity, i.e., physical power, than their unprivileged neighbours, we will once again have a social elite, just like the old aristocrats, whose weapons could enable them to enslave the unarmed. Is it worth it? Or should we just out and out ban all guns entirely? Afterall, who needs a gun if nobody else has one? Only the weak, and they are those who the police are supposed to serve and protect, but don't. But that's another issue.
